Tony Curtis was born Bernard Schwartz on June 3, 1925, in the Bronx, New York. He was the youngest of three sons to Jewish immigrant parents, who owned a tailor shop. Curtis grew up in a modest home, where his parents instilled in him a strong work ethic and a love for the performing arts.

Curtis began his acting career in the 1940s, landing small roles on Broadway and in film. He soon changed his name to Tony Curtis, which he felt better suited his charming and debonair persona. His breakthrough came in 1952 with the role of Sidney Falco in the critically acclaimed film "Sweet Smell of Success."

Curtis's film career flourished in the 1950s and 1960s, with notable performances in films such as "Some Like It Hot" (1959), "Spartacus" (1960), and "Operation Petticoat" (1959). He became known for his dashing good looks, charming smile, and versatility in playing a wide range of roles.

Throughout his career, Curtis worked with some of the most iconic directors of the time, including Billy Wilder, Stanley Kubrick, and John Huston. He was also a talented painter and sculptor, and his artwork was exhibited in galleries and museums.

Curtis was married five times and had two daughters, Jamie and Allegra. He was a devoted father and was known for his kind and generous nature. Despite struggling with addiction and personal demons, Curtis remained a beloved figure in Hollywood and was beloved by his fans.

Tony Curtis passed away on September 29, 2010, at the age of 85, leaving behind a legacy as one of the most enduring and charismatic actors of Hollywood's Golden Age.

Anthony Jerome Curtis, professionally known as Tony Curtis, was an American actor born on June 3, 1925, in the Bronx, New York City. He was the youngest of three children to Helen and Julius Curtis, a Belgian immigrant and an immigrant from Ukraine, respectively.

Curtis's early life was marked by poverty and instability, with his family moving frequently due to financial struggles. He eventually dropped out of high school and joined the U.S. Naval Reserve in 1943, serving until 1945. During his naval service, he met his future brother-in-law, actor James Whitmore, who encouraged him to pursue an acting career.

Curtis began his acting career in the late 1940s, starting with small roles on stage and screen. He made his film debut in 1949's "Criss Cross" and gradually gained recognition with his performances in films like "Houdini" (1953) and "Son of Ali Baba" (1952). His breakthrough role came in 1958 with "Some Like It Hot," a comedy starring alongside Jack Lemmon and Marilyn Monroe, which earned him a Golden Globe nomination.

Throughout the 1960s and 1970s, Curtis appeared in a wide range of films, including dramas, comedies, and even action movies. Some notable works include "Spartacus" (1960), "Operation Petticoat" (1959), and "Taras Bulba" (1962). He also starred in several successful television series, such as "The Persuaders!" (1971-1972) and "The Tony Curtis Show" (1967).

Curtis was also a talented painter and sculptor, with his artwork showcased in galleries and exhibitions. He wrote an autobiography, "Telling Tales: A Memoir," which was published in 2008.

Tony Curtis was married five times, including to actresses Janet Leigh and Christine Kaufmann. He had two daughters, Jamie Lee Curtis (actress) and Kelly Curtis (actress and producer), with his first wife, Janet Leigh.

Curtis passed away on September 29, 2010, at the age of 85, due to complications from a cardiac arrest. His legacy as a talented and versatile actor continues to be celebrated, with his films still entertaining audiences today.
